Abstract:
Background: Post‐stroke hemispheric cerebral edema manifests as the formation of perilesional cysts (PLCs), which results from a lack of compensation and fluid imbalance between cerebral tissue and perilesional interstitial fluid. Perilesional interstitial fluid volume expands due to increased local edema and inflammation as well as decreased fluid resorption. The proposed mechanism of action is to promote clearance of edema and interstitial fluid, as well as reduce inflammation and tissue swelling. 20 patients will be initially enrolled in each dose group. The primary safety outcome will be an evaluation of dose‐limiting toxicity (DLT). The primary efficacy outcome will be efficacy assessment of PLC on diffusion weighted imaging (DWI) MRI at weeks 2 and 8. A dose expansion Phase 2 study will be conducted if 2 or fewer of the 20 patients in a given arm experience DLT. Methods: Eligible participants are aged 18 to 80, have suffered a stroke within 2‐28 days prior to enrollment, and have a hemorrhagic infarct of at least 4cm2 and a PLC. Patients will be hospitalized for four weeks and monitored at 2‐week intervals. This project will result in the use of 464 participants. Patients will be enrolled sequentially by dose. Three consecutive patients will be enrolled in each dose group. Dose escalation may occur when two or fewer patients experience a dose‐limiting toxicity (DLT). The study arms will be: Dose A (13‐15 mg/kg once a week), Dose B (20‐25 mg/kg once a week), Dose C (25‐35 mg/kg once a week). Abstract:
The purpose of this study was to examine the effects of a 12‐week training programme, which combined cognitive training and exercise training, on executive skills in patients with chronic schizophrenia, and its role in reducing disease‐specific and treatment‐related symptoms. Patients were randomly assigned to either the training group (n = 35) or the control group (n = 36). The training group received training for 6 months on 17 tasks, and the exercise group participated in aerobic exercise only. The Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST), the Tower of Hanoi (TOH) test, the symbol‐digit modalities test (SDMT), and the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale Ⅱnd edition (WAIS‐II) were used to assess executive skills in executive function. Changes in psychopathology were assessed using the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS). The training group showed a significant improvement in the total score of the WCST compared with the control group. These results provide support for a multimodal approach involving cognitive remediation and exercise training for the treatment of executive dysfunction in patients with schizophrenia.

Brief Summary
-----------------
The goal of this study is to identify an actionable target for a patient's cancer for inclusion in clinical trials that are currently either open or in the pipeline at the Sarah Cannon Research Institute. Biomarker testing is conducted on samples of disease tissue to help determine if a drug will be effective against a certain patient's tumor. Tumors that have a specific genetic mutation may have an increased likelihood of responding to the drug. This identification enables targeted therapy development that may result in improved patient outcomes. Biomarker testing is conducted on archived tumor tissue and a new biopsy.

Study Overview
=================

Brief Summary
-----------------
Early diagnosis and intervention could promote tumor prognosis and improve patient survival. At the same time, it also provides a good chance for patients to undergo radical surgery. However, during the early cancer stage, the tumor is not easy to identify by using traditional imaging techniques. In order to further improve the detection ability of early cancer, the early detection of endoscope ultrasound-based contrast enhanced imaging has attracted the attention of researchers.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Lung cancer is the most common cause of cancer-related death in the world, and early-stage disease is rarely detected because of a lack of early symptoms. A variety of tumor markers can be used to screen for early or locally advanced non-small cell lung cancer, including CEA, NSE, and so on. In addition, a variety of imaging detection means can be used to detect lung nodules, such as CT, MRI, and so on. However, some of the abovementioned tumor markers have high false positive and false negative rates, and some imaging tools have problems such as high false positive and false negative rates, high cost, and radiation. At the same time, only a few patients can be screened for early tumors, and the curative effect of treatment such as surgery on early tumors is greatly improved. This paper designs an intelligent early lung cancer screening platform based on CT images. The platform uses computer vision technology to optimize the lesion detection algorithm to solve the problem of low detection efficiency of early lesions. At the same time, a new algorithm of early lung lesion diagnosis is established, so as to realize the more accurate detection of early lung cancer.

Additionally, diabetic foot ulcers are known to have high recurrence rates, and there is a lack of effective preventive strategies. By targeting the diabetic population, the study aims to fill this gap in knowledge and provide evidence-based recommendations for preventing foot ulcers in this high-risk population. 

The intervention/treatment was chosen based on the findings of a systematic review, which identified that the Walt Disney method, a type of structured storytelling, can be an effective tool for providing social support, enhancing self-efficacy, and promoting healthy lifestyle changes in diabetic patients. Therefore, using this technique for providing individualized education sessions may help to improve their foot care practices and reduce the incidence of foot ulcers.

Overall, by conducting this randomized controlled trial, we hope to provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of the Walt Disney method in preventing foot ulcers among diabetic patients. This information is crucial for healthcare providers to develop evidence-based strategies for improving foot care outcomes in this high-risk population.

Abstract:
Background: 
The aim of the current study is to assess the efficacy, tolerability, and safety of the combination of Crizotinib, Aspirin, and Methotrexate in the treatment of patients with advanced biliary tract cancer. Methods: From November 2016 to November 2018, a prospective single‐arm nonrandomized Phase 2 trial will be conducted in patients with advanced biliary tract cancer. Patients will receive orally 400 mga of crizotinib on days 1–7 every four weeks, aspirin 100 mg twice weekly, and methotrexate 6.5 mg/m2 weekly on days 1, 8, 15, and 22. The primary endpoint of this study is progression‐free survival. Secondary endpoints are safety and overall survival, and objective response rate. Discussion: The combination of crizotinib, aspirin, and methotrexate has demonstrated an excellent safety profile in other cancers, including gastric cancer and NSCLC. Patients with advanced biliary tract cancer have few treatment options available and have a prognosis of 6 months and a response rate of <14%. Crizotinib is the standard therapy for the treatment of lung cancer following EGFR mutation, and EGFR mutations are frequently expressed in gallbladder and cholangiocarcinoma. This clinical trial will assess the efficacy of the EGFR inhibitor Crizotinib combined with aspirin and methotrexate for advanced biliary tract cancer.

Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the feasibility of the use of the BENEFIT trial design in a cancer clinical trial aimed at improving patients' ability to identify and manage adverse effects of cancer treatment and improving physical and mental symptoms. The results may have implications for future cancer research designed to incorporate behavioral treatment into standard oncologic care.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This study explores the recruitment feasibility and treatment acceptability of using a brief, multi-session web-based intervention to promote a better understanding of common symptoms and treatment side effects in women who were recently diagnosed with gynecologic cancer. The specific aims are to: 1) assess treatment acceptability during the recruitment period among 30 cancer patients approached to determine their level of interest in the trial, and 2) obtain detailed information about the experience of 30 participants who complete at least one web-based session and complete the consent process to allow for assessment of the feasibility of trial participation. Participants will be assessed by phone at enrollment and immediately following treatment. Outcomes will include treatment acceptability, satisfaction, treatment integrity, recruitment efficiency, and retention. Interviews will be conducted with up to 20 participants to examine their experience with the study processes and strategies to improve future implementation of the intervention.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: It is estimated that 50% of patients currently receiving psychiatric treatment have both opioid use disorder (OUD) and chronic pain. Evidence suggests that behavioral interventions, such as Tai Chi, may be effective in managing symptoms of anxiety and chronic pain. This study aims to examine the feasibility, acceptability, and potential effects of Virtual Tai Chi Easy in patients with OUD, anxiety, and chronic pain. DESIGN: A single‐group randomized control trial (RCT) study design will be used where individuals in active treatment will be allocated to the Tai Chi Easy arm. Individuals on the wait‐list will receive the Tai Chi Easy after 8 weeks/16 sessions. The trial is comprised of three arms: Active Treatment, Wait‐List Control, and Enriched Enrollment Control. The Intervention component of the study is a virtual version of a behavioral intervention called Tai Chi Easy, which is a manualized 8‐week group‐based intervention that incorporates elements of cognitive‐behavioral therapy (CBT), exercise science, and traditional Chinese medicine. CBT includes gentle movement, breath practice, self‐massage, and meditation. Exercise science components include an emphasis on balance training, muscle relaxation, and overall body awareness. Traditional Chinese medicine components include the study of Tai Chi, a movement exercise that emphasizes mind‐body integration. A Tai Chi Easy treatment manual was developed based on established methods of intervention development that includes systematic reviews, synthesis of empirical evidence, expert consultation, and a pilot feasibility study. We conducted a pilot feasibility study in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, that yielded promising findings but did not meet our enrollment goals. We will use a sequential multiple assignment randomized trial (SMART) design, where individuals in active treatment will be allocated to the Virtual Tai Chi Easy arm. The study will be conducted as follows: 
The patients will be under mechanical ventilation for at least 24 hours. After informed consent is obtained, the patients will be in the prone position for 16 hours. During this period, the patients will be monitored by EIT every 4 hours to measure ventilation-perfusion matching. The patients will be in the supine position for another 8 hours, and the EIT monitoring will be performed every 2 hours during this period. 
The study will be terminated earlier than expected if the patient shows any of the following: 
1. Respiratory failure 
2. Hemodynamic instability 
3. Severe deterioration of organ function 
4. Death 
5. Withdrawal of life-sustaining therapy 

Target number of participants: 50

It is well known that CARDS results in diffuse pulmonary damage and reduced ventilation-perfusion matching. In non-COVID19-ARDS, the distribution of ventilation-perfusion mismatch is heterogeneous, with more ventilation in the dorsal lung. In CARDS, by contrast, the ventilation-perfusion mismatch is more uniform throughout the lungs, with less dorsal-ventral gradients.

In this study, we aim to determine the effect of prone positioning on ventilation-perfusion matching in COVID19-associated ARDS (CARDS) and non-COVID19-associated ARDS (non-CARDS). By measuring the pulmonary function using electrical impedance tomography (EIT) before and after proning, we will compare the changes in ventilation-perfusion matching between the two groups to understand the mechanism of CARDS and guide clinical management.

Generally, Part A of the study, which consists of the dose escalation and expansion arms, is open to patients with advanced or metastatic solid tumors who have progressed after a platinum-based chemotherapy regimen and have received no more than two prior lines of systemic therapy for metastatic disease. There may be exceptions based on the nature of the diseases. For example, colon cancer and breast cancer patients who received fewer than three lines of treatment may be eligible. Some study arms may also have eligibility restrictions based on the prior treatments received. For example, some patients may be excluded if they have received any prior treatment with checkpoint inhibitors, such as cemiplimab, or if they have been treated with anti PD-1/L1 therapies. 

Study hypothesis
=================
SNS-101 binds with high affinity and specificity to VISTA, a cell surface molecule overexpressed on regulatory T cells and T cells that is involved in peripheral tolerance. SNS-101 blocks the inhibitory effects of VISTA on T cell function, leading to increased T cell activation, thereby providing an opportunity to overcome tumor-mediated immunosuppression and unleash a more potent antitumor immune response.

Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: To analyze the relationship between the occurrence of myocardial ischemia syndrome and the increase of CRP (C‐reactive protein) during a 16‐week diet in 58 female hypercholesterolemic patients. PATIENT AND METHODS: The study population consisted of 58 female hypercholesterolemic patients (49‐77 years of age) with a mean serum cholesterol level of 7.17 +/‐ 0.90 mmol/l (N=58). Twenty‐nine patients were selected to test a low saturated fat, high carbohydrate diet (n=15) and a low saturated fat, high unsaturated fat diet (n=14). The other 29 patients were selected to test a low carbohydrate, high saturated fat diet (n=14) and a low carbohydrate, high unsaturated fat diet (n=15). All 58 patients received their assigned diet for 16 weeks. The control of cardiovascular risk factors, blood biochemistry, and inflammatory markers were made at the beginning and at the end of the assigned period and, in case of persistence of symptoms, they were further evaluated with Holter.RESULTS: The high unsaturated fat diet had a similar effect on the serum cholesterol level in the two diets, as well as a similar effect on blood pressure. The increase of serum triglycerides was more pronounced on the carbohydrate diet, but lipoprotein levels remained almost identical. Inflammatory markers were similar in both diets, so they were all grouped together. A decrease in serum CRP occurred in all cases, with the exception of patients on the carbohydrate diet. The control of the clinical status was satisfactory in both diets.CONCLUSION: In this study population, we did not find significant differences between diets, but only differences between dietary regimens in the increase of serum triglycerides and serum CRP.

1. Primary outcome: sexual response based on the sexual response cycle described by Masters and Johnson, where different phases of sexual arousal:
- The desire phase: The desire phase is a state of sexual excitement that begins with the perception of erotic stimuli.
- The excitement phase: This is the second phase of the sexual response cycle. The sexual organs become highly responsive during this phase and the person experiences rapid breathing, increased heart rate, vaginal lubrication, and swelling and dilation of the blood vessels in the penis, which can lead to an erection. Excitement phase is essential for the development of orgasm.
- The orgasm phase: An orgasm occurs when a person reaches an intense state of sexual excitement and release, accompanied by muscle contractions and a release of sexual tension.
- The resolution (or refractory) phase: This is the final stage when the body returns to a calm, relaxed state.

It is common for both men and women to experience sexual dysfunction at some point in their lives, and it can occur as a result of physical or psychological factors.
The most common sexual dysfunctions in women include: Hypoactive sexual desire disorder: this is a condition in which a woman has a low level of sexual desire or lacks interest in sexual activity. Abstract:
Background: To investigate the effect of intraoral nitrous oxide‐oxygen on children during dental treatment. Methods: This study was approved by the institutional review board of our university. This study was a randomized controlled trial study. Patients are randomly assigned to two groups. The study group was inhalation of 100% nitrous oxide‐oxygen in dental treatment. The control group was inhalation of air to perform the dental treatment. Oxygen saturation (O2) and heart rate (HR) will be measured at 5 time points. After the dental treatment, the visual analog scale (VAS) of postoperative pain is measured. The duration of dental treatment is recorded. Results: 80 patients were enrolled in this study. No significant between group differences were observed for O2 and HR at any assessment time points or VAS of postoperative pain. The duration of dental treatment was found to be significantly different between the study and control group. Conclusion: Nitrous oxide has the same sedative effect on patients during dental treatment.

Background: Many studies have shown that yoga therapy has a positive impact on mental health and physical wellbeing. It can reduce stress levels, improve sleep quality, enhance immunity, and increase flexibility and strength. However, most of these studies have focused on individual or group yoga sessions, rather than yoga therapy provided by a qualified yoga therapist. Additionally, many health conditions are associated with mental health issues, such as stress and anxiety, which can affect the effectiveness of the therapy. Therefore, this study aims to assess the efficacy of yoga therapy provided by a yoga therapist in improving the mental health and physical wellbeing of patients with health conditions affected by stress and anxiety. Methods: This randomized control trial will be conducted on 70 patients diagnosed with health conditions that are associated with stress and anxiety. The patients will be randomly allocated into two groups: a yoga therapy group and a control group. The yoga therapy group will receive 12 sessions of yoga therapy provided by a qualified yoga therapist, while the control group will receive standard care for their health condition. The primary outcome measures will be stress and anxiety, measured using the Perceived Stress Scale (PSS) and the Generalised Anxiety Disorder (GAD‐7) scale, respectively. All the statistical analyspectives will be done by using the IBM SPSS Statistics software (version 26). The significance level will be set at p < 0.05.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Sphincter hypertonia is the most common type of urinary dysfunction after spinal cord injury (SCI). It causes incomplete emptying of the bladder leading to residual urine. The primary objective of the study will be to compare the efficiency of trans‐sphincter injections of botulinum toxin vs. onabotulinumtoxinA in patients with urinary retention after SCI with regards to efficiency in the treatment of urinary hyper‐reflexia and reduction of postvoid residual urine. We hypothesize that in case of sphincter hyper‐reflexia the injection of trans‐sphincter Botox will lead to more durable relief than onabotulinumtoxinA. DESIGN/SETTING/PATIENTS: This study is a prospective, double‐blind, randomized, controlled trial. It will be conducted in the Department of Urology‐Urodynamics, Medical University of Warsaw. Patients who were clinically assessed for a spinal lesion for a few months before the study with residual urinary flow over 100 ml after 4 hours will be included in the study. The study will include 30 patients, 15 in each group. A simple randomization method will be applied. The primary endpoint will be the difference in the proportion of responders in the 2 groups after the treatment. We hypothesize that there will be at least 15% higher efficiency of the injection of Botox compared to onabotulinumtoxinA based on previous study reports. The secondary endpoint will assess the difference in the treatment duration between the 2 groups. The differences in the treatment duration between the 2 groups will be tested for normality and if it will be normally distributed we will use the Student t‐test, otherwise we will use the Mann‐Whitney U test. The effect of each intervention will be analyzed in terms of the mean difference in the treatment duration, standard deviation and 95% confidence intervals. A difference of 1 week in the treatment duration will be considered significant (type II error (b)) β=0.2). The statistical analysis will be done using the SPSS v

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of Yoga therapy in comparison with Physiotherapy on pain, physical function, quality of life, fatigue, depression and self‐efficacy in patients with axial spondyloarthritis (axSPA). Methods: 72 patients with axSPA will be randomly allocated to either a ten‐week Yoga program or a conventional Physiotherapy program with equal number of sessions. The primary outcome measures are pain intensity and physical function. Changes on the other secondary measures (including quality of life, fatigue, depression, self‐efficacy scores) will be compared between groups. Discussion: The overall aim of this study is to investigate the effects of Yoga therapy in comparison with Physiotherapy on pain, physical function, quality of life, fatigue, depression and self‐efficacy in patients with axial spondyloarthritis.

Sleep is a natural, healthy, and complex behavior that is essential for the proper development and functioning of the body and mind. During this study, we will investigate whether different behavioral sleep interventions will provide optimal outcomes, as well as the effects of the intervention on mental health and behavioral outcomes for children. This study aims to determine how the addition of parental training or behavior modification will affect outcomes, as well as the impact of these parental interventions on parents' mental health. This study will include three groups: an intervention group, an intervention group with parental training, and a control group receiving usual care. All groups will receive a behavioral treatment, namely, behavioral sleep treatment, and the participants will record their child's sleep outcomes for four weeks using a sleep diary. The researchers will then determine the child's sleep outcomes based on the treatment they received.

-----------------
The purpose of this study is to assess the safety and effectiveness of 4 grams (4,000 mg) of a daily dose of XEN1101 in controlling focal onset seizures in patients with epilepsy.

-----------------
This is a Phase 3, open-label, multicenter, long-term extension (LTE) study of XEN1101 in patients with focal epilepsy. The study will consist of a screening period, a treatment period, and a follow-up period. The treatment period will be 12 months. The follow-up period will be 12 months.

Primary outcome measure
=================
1. Quality of life will be measured using the Burn Specific Quality of LIfe ShortForm (BQOL-SF). The BQOL-SF is a 24-item instrument that assesses the impact of burns injury on different aspects of quality of life, such as physical health, emotional health, and social functioning.
2. Emotional distress will be measured using the General Health Questionnaire (GHQ). The GHQ is a 12-item instrument that measures different aspects of emotional distress, such as anxiety, depression, and social dysfunction.

Secondary outcome measures
=================
1. Skin lesions will be measured using the National Burn Study (NBS) burn wound scale. The NBS burn wound scale is a 7-item instrument that assesses different aspects of skin lesions, such as size, depth, and presence of infection.
2. Pain intensity will be measured using the Visual Analog Score (VAS). The VAS is a 10-cm line that patients use to rate the intensity of their pain on a scale of 0-10, with 0 indicating no pain and 10 indicating the worst pain imaginable.
3. Scar appearance will be measured using the Psoriasis Area and Severity Index (PASI). The PASI is a 3-item instrument that assesses the severity of psoriasis, including redness, scaling, and thickness of the skin.

Study of the Influence of Stereotactic Radiotherapy for Patients with Small Cell Lung Cancer Residual After Sublobar Surgical Treatment

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Lung cancer is the most common lethal cancer in humans in the world and 70% of all lung cancers are non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The disease incidence of small cell lung cancer (SCLC) accounts for about 10% of lung cancers in the world. According to the 2017 Chinese lung cancer experts' consensus, patients with lung cancer after surgical resection were given postoperative radiotherapy. If the tumor remains after surgery due to inadequate resection of the tumor (positive resection margin), there will be a 50% chance of relapse within 1 year. Among patients with residual tumors after sublobar resection, radiotherapy is generally performed until the lung volume is less than 1/3 of the total lung capacity. The purpose of this study is to retrospectively evaluate the influence of Stereotactic Body Radiotherapy (SBRT) on patients with lung volume less than 1/3 of the total lung volume.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Postoperative adjuvant radiotherapy has been confirmed to be effective in reducing the recurrence rate of NSCLC after sublobar lung resection. In view of the small percentage of SCLC, few cases of the tumor residue after sublobar lung resection have been reported, especially postoperative radiotherapy, few cases of postoperative SBRT have been reported. The purpose of this study is to evaluate whether SBRT can reduce the recurrence rate after sublobar radical resection for patients with limited disease small cell lung cancer. It is hypothesized that stereotactic body radiotherapy can significantly reduce the 2-year recurrence rate of small cell lung cancer tumor residual after partial lobectomy, thereby improving the survival rate of patients with tumor residual after partial lobectomy. To provide evidence for patients with small cell lung cancer tumor residual after partial lobectomy, this study will analyze the postoperative efficacy of small cell lung cancer patients with 3-year survival or less tumor residual after sublob

Participants will score a Brief Resiliency Scale score of 6.5 out of 25. This score indicates "somewhat vulnerable," which means that individuals in this condition have a higher potential for resilience.Resilience is a psychometrically supported construct. Specifically, resilience is conceptualized as a trait that is linked to multiple aspects of health, including physical and mental well-being. While there is no definitive way to measure the construct, a variety of tools have been developed to assess resilience. One widely used measure is the Brief Resiliency Scale, a self-report questionnaire that measures the tendency to bounce back from stressful events. Studies have found that higher resilience scores are associated with better physical and mental health outcomes. For instance, individuals with high resilience are more likely to maintain their physical health and report lower rates of depression and anxiety. They are also better able to cope with stress and adversity, and they tend to have higher life

Study objectives
=================
The primary objective of the study is to evaluate the efficacy of the NexPara® 6275 vaccine.
Endpoint of the study
=================
The primary endpoint of the study is the occurrence of disease following vaccination. The secondary objective of the study is to assess the vaccine's safety and immunogenicity.

Study design
=================
This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. The study will be divided into two phases: the primary phase and the secondary phase. The primary phase will be a 14-day monitoring period for the first 3 cohorts, and the secondary phase will be a 7-day monitoring period for the remaining cohorts.

Intervention
=================
Participants will receive a single injection of the NexPara® 6275 vaccine or a placebo. The primary phase will involve two injections of the vaccine or placebo, and the secondary phase will involve a third injection. Both doses will be given at least 14 days apart.

The vaccine will be administered by intramuscular injection. The placebo will be administered by intramuscular injection with saline.

The study will enroll 150 healthy adults aged 18-64. The 150 participants will be divided into 50 dosing groups of 3.

Outcome of the study
=================
The outcome of the study will be the occurrence of disease following vaccination. The primary endpoint of the study will be the occurrence of disease during the primary phase. The secondary endpoint of the study will be the occurrence of disease during the secondary phase.

Follow-up and Data collection
=================
All participants will be followed for 14 days for the primary phase and 7 days for the secondary phase. Follow-up visits will be conducted at days 3, 7, and 14 following vaccination.

Data on the occurrence of disease and adverse events will be collected at each follow-up visit. The occurrence of disease will be defined as the development of clinical symptoms of disease within 14 days of vaccination or the presence of specific signs of disease during the study period.

The experimental group will all receive the "Integrated Rehabilitation Program for Chronic Wounds With Multiple Comorbidities" intervention. The intervention consists of a combination of cognitive-behavioral and physiotherapy-focused treatment strategies to improve physical activity, reduce depression and anxiety, and promote self-care behaviors. The intervention will be delivered by an occupational therapist and a physiotherapist in a group setting for 8 weeks. The specific contents of the intervention include the following: physical activity promotion: Participants will receive instruction on how to perform physical exercises and perform home-based physical activity with the assistance of a physical therapist. These physical activities will focus on strengthening, balance, and endurance, and will be individualized based on the participant's fitness level and goals. Cognitive-behavioral therapy: Participants will receive cognitive-behavioral therapy to address depression and anxiety symptoms. Group activities will be used to promote social support and provide a supportive environment for participants to share their experiences and learn from each other. Self-care behavior promotion: Participants will be encouraged to engage in healthy habits such as quitting smoking or drinking and improving sleep quality. They will also be educated on the importance of proper wound care, including the use of compression garments and dressing changes. Group discussion and feedback: Participants will have the opportunity to engage in group discussions and receive feedback on their progress. The intervention will be delivered twice a week for 8 weeks.

Detailed Description

Background Psychiatric disorders account for half of the disability among active duty military personnel and are associated with reduced readiness, increased medical health care costs, and medical and operational performance decrements. Despite the high prevalence and tremendous impact of major depressive disorder (MDD) and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) on the military, interventions currently available to military service members are limited and face poor adherence. To address this treatment gap, our team has developed an integrative treatment platform, a mobile-based cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and medication management app called Army Health for Soldiers. In a pilot study, we demonstrated that Soldiers in Army Health use it frequently, report symptom remission after using Army Health for a total of just eight weeks, and most would recommend that family members use the mobile app as well. These results highlight the potential of mobile behavioral interventions in the military setting. Despite these preliminary findings, a definitive trial to test the efficacy of the Army Health approach is necessary. Army Health's use of evidence-based CBT to improve symptoms of anxiety and depression, coupled with integrated primary care and prescription management and an innovative coaching platform, makes it well-positioned for further study. Abstract:
The aim of this study was to assess the feasibility and acceptability of a novel 6‐week behavioral intervention for children aged 8‐12 years with overweight or obesity, and to evaluate parent and child acceptability and feasibility of the intervention in families with 1 child or twins. METHODS: Parents' acceptability of the intervention was examined over the 6‐week period, and a single follow‐up assessment was conducted at 3 months to assess maintenance rates for the intervention, the impact of social support and physical activity from parents, and perceptions of intervention effects. Fifty‐six parents of children aged 8‐12 years (20 male, 41% Hispanic) with overweight or obesity (BMI>85th percentile) or obesity (BMI>95th percentile) were involved in the study. Parents received 2 60 min phone sessions from a registered dietitian and were asked to follow a reduced energy balance meal plan. Children received two 30 min phone sessions from a pediatric exercise physiologist during which physical activity recommendations (>120 min/day) were provided. Parent‐reported acceptability was high (90% were "Very Satisfied" and "Satisfied") and children reported that they had "Lots of fun" on a total of 75.4% of days spent exercising. On average, children were physically active for 0.0 minutes/day prior to the intervention, and this increased to 77 minutes, 56 minutes, and 42 minutes/week, respectively, at 1, 2, and 3‐month follow‐up assessments. After 6 weeks and 3 months, 47% and 42%, respectively, of parents reported that they had been able to consistently implement the proposed diet changes.CONCLUSIONS: The findings from this pilot study demonstrate the feasibility of a family‐based intervention for overweight or obese children aged 8‐12 years. Although further research is required to confirm the efficacy of the intervention, the results indicate that parental and child engagement with the intervention was high and that the program may be easily implemented in clinical settings

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is an open-label, phase 3 trial to determine if the combination of the anti-CD38 chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell therapy (CAR-T) lisocabtagene maraleucel (liso-cel; JCAR017) and the B-cell maturation antigen (BCMA) CAR-T belantamab mafodotin (Bel-cel; JNJ-68284528) is superior to daratumumab (Dara) combined with bortezomib, lenalidomide, and dexamethasone (DVd) as second-line therapy in participants who have relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma (RRMM).

Detailed Description
-----------------
Subjects who have responded in the first line treatment should be at least 6 months off therapy or after disease relapse / first progression. Subjects with minimal residual disease ≥ 10- 4 (MRD ≥ 10-4) on first-line are allowed to enroll if disease relapsed or progressed. Up to 50% of subjects, of their choice, randomized to each arm (within arm) may be allowed to convert to the second arm for further enrollment and treatment after disease progression.

The Study of a BCMA-Targeted Immune Construct (CART-BCMA) in Subjects With Relapsed or Refractory Multiple Myeloma

The treatment schedule consists of one cycle, which lasts for 3 weeks. During this cycle, Cemiplimab will be administered intravenously every 3 weeks, while Ziv-Aflibercept will be administered intravenously every 2 weeks.

The design of the experimental arm with the combination of Cemiplimab and Ziv-Aflibercept was chosen for several reasons. Firstly, the combination therapy allows us to target multiple pathways involved in tumor growth and immune evasion, potentially leading to a more potent anti-tumor effect. Secondly, the treatment schedule and dosing regimen were designed to optimize the benefits of both drugs while minimizing the risk of toxicity. Regular monitoring of organ and marrow function, as well as echocardiogram assessments, will ensure participant safety throughout the trial.

Intervention Details:
- Ziv-Aflibercept is an investigational or experimental anti-cancer agent that inactivates vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) from functioning. It has been shown to prevent the formation of new blood vessels in tumors and inhibit tumor growth. Blocking VEGF may also enhance the immune response against cancer.
- Cemiplimab is a human monoclonal anti-PD-1 antibody that works by blocking the programmed death-1 (PD-1) receptor on immune cells. This helps enhance the immune response against cancer cells.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study will enroll participants who will undergo laparoscopic cholecystectomy for symptomatic gallbladder disease. Preoperative depression score will be calculated by using the Patient Health Questionarie-2 (PHQ2) and the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) as well as by a pre-operative depression diagnosis in clinical practice. We will assess postoperative chronic pain and quality of life over a period of 9 months. Patients will also undergo blood testing for serum levels of serotonin and tryptophan.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to detect the impact of depression on the outcome, namely chronic pain, after cholecystectomy for uncomplicated gallstone. The first objective of this study is to assess the risk of chronic pain development according to the 3 preoperative PHQ2 and preoperative depression diagnosis during clinical evaluation after laparoscopic cholecystectomy for uncomplicated gallstone. The second objective is to detect the impact of perioperative depression diagnosis on the quality of life and the long-term chronic pain development after uncomplicated laparoscopic cholecystectomy for symptomatic gallstones. The third objective is to study the relationship between preoperative serum serotonin and tryptophan concentrations and postoperative chronic pain and quality of life after cholecystectomy. 210 patients who had laparoscopic cholecystectomy for symptomatic gallstone will be recruited. The study will consist of 5 periods: first period is recruiting patients in the department of Anesthesiology, and it will last approximately 8 months. Patients will then be randomized in 2 arms; the first arm is for the patients who will undergo PHQ2, Beck Depression Inventory, as well as the pre-op depression diagnose. Patients will be treated as usual. The second arm is for the patients who will undergo routine preoperative screening, and no test will be performed. They will be treated as usual. This period will last approximately 4 months.

Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
The prevalence of Diabetes Mellitus has reached epidemic proportions globally. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus is the most common form of diabetes and more common in people who are overweight or obese. Studies have repeatedly demonstrated that BMI is a strong predictor of insulin resistance in non-obese individuals, and in such studies, weight reduction has improved glycemic control. There is evidence that in type 1 diabetes, obesity is associated with an increased incidence of diabetic nephropathy, neuropathy, retinopathy, and atherosclerosis. This study will attempt to determine if the reduction in insulin dosage as a result of weight reduction in overweight patients with type 1 diabetes will yield improved glycemic control and a reduction in inflammatory parameters. Patients with type 1 diabetes are screened as to eligibility and if so, have a weight history taken and anthropometric measurements done. Blood samples are sent for insulin dosage estimation and for testing for Incretin hormones (Glucagon-Like-Peptide 1, Glucose-Dependent Insulinotropic Polypeptide and Amylin). Okay, based on the information you've provided, I have some suggestions for the design of your study arms. For the active comparator arm, I recommend using the Hot EMR technique. This involves an initial submucosal injection of physiological solution and methylene blue, followed by 'piece-meal' resection using a 10 or 15 millimeter diathermic snare and ablation of the margins with the snare tip. This arm will serve as a comparison to evaluate the conventional hot EMR technique.

For the experimental arm, I suggest using the Cold EMR technique. This involves an initial submucosal injection of physiological solution and methylene blue, followed by 'piece-meal' resection using a dedicated cold snare. This technique is hypothesized to have advantages such as reduced thermal injury and potentially lower recurrence rates. By comparing this arm to the hot EMR arm, you can determine if the cold EMR technique is a feasible alternative for large colonic adenomas.

Brief summary
=================
Myocardial infarction (MI) and atrial fibrillation (AF) are two common cardiovascular diseases that often coexist in patients. The main treatment for MI and AF is pharmacological therapy, and patients with both conditions are often prescribed a combination of drugs. However, these medications can have side effects that can reduce physical activity levels. Reduced physical activity can lead to other health problems, such as obesity, diabetes, and depression, which can worsen the prognosis for patients with heart disease.  The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of group education via Zoom® video meetings for reducing kinesiophobia and promoting physical activity in patients with MI and/or AF. The aim of this study is to reduce kinesiophobia and promote physical activity among patients with MI and/or AF. Kinesiophobia, or fear of movement, is a psychological barrier that can prevent patients from engaging in physical activity. Physical inactivity can lead to negative health consequences and reduce the quality of life in patients with heart disease.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: A prospective, single‐institution cohort study, analyzing surgical and imaging outcomes associated with the use of intraindividual bilateral rectus sheath biopsies vs. routine incisional biopsies in patients undergoing elective major colon or rectal resection was undertaken.METHODS: A total of 292 consecutive elective major lower gastrointestinal resections between 2011 and 2015 were prospectively identified by an EMR search. Patients with biopsy proven primary colonic or rectal cancer with prior or concurrent chemotherapy treated by intraindividual bilateral (N = 69) or routine incisional biopsy (N = 170) were included. We compared disease‐free and overall survival (DFS, OS) in a non‐randomized trial. The primary endpoint of this study was DFS.RESULTS: Intragroup analysis of patients undergoing bilateral incisional biopsies (N = 29), those with positive lymph nodes (pN+) had shorter DFS and OS in comparison to patients with negative lymph nodes (pN0) (38 % vs. 72 %, p = .002; Kaplan‐Meier estimate [Log rank (LR)‐Test]). Contrary, patients undergoing bilateral intraindividual rectus sheath biopsies (N = 40) had no significant differences in DFS (29 % vs. 42 %, p = .163 [LR‐Test]). The intragroup analysis of patients undergoing bilateral incisional biopsy (N = 29) revealed no significant differences in DFS (29 % vs. 42 % [LR‐Test]). The overall survival showed an equivalent median survival in both groups of between 18 months and 5 years postoperatively. The recurrence sites were comparable in each study population.CONCLUSION: Intraindividual bilateral biopsy of the rectus sheet might be an effective alternative to routine rectal and colonic incisional biopsies with regard to safety and disease‐free survivals. Abstract:
The use of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) is associated with increased risk of community‐acquired pneumonia (CAP) and Clostridium difficile infection (CDI). This study aimed to determine whether PPI use is associated with increased CAP‐related and CDI‐related hospitalization in a population‐based setting. We extracted the data of PPI users from the Taiwan National Health Insurance Research Database (2000‐2014). The primary outcomes were first‐time CAP‐related and CDI‐related hospitalizations between 2000 and 2014. In total, there were 2,032,114 PPI users, with a mean age of 72.14 +/‐ 14.99 y. Among all patients, the incidence densities were 1.72 (95% confidence interval [CI]: 1.71‐1.73) for CDI and 3.94 (95% CI: 3.93‐3.96) for CAP. After adjusting for covariates, we found that the PPI group did not have a significant increased risk of hospitalization due to CAP and CDI (hazard ratio: 1.03, 95% CI: 1.01‐1.04 and hazard ratio: 0.99, 95% CI: 0.97‐1.00, respectively). Among users who switched PPI brands (101,061), the 2nd brands (lansoprazole, esomeprazole, rabeprazole, and pantoprazole) did not significantly change the risk of hospitalization due to CAP or CDI. In conclusion, PPI use was not significantly associated with increased risk of hospitalization due to CAP or CDI. Further investigations are needed to evaluate the risk of CAP and CDI in those who switched PPI brands. Copyright [2022] by the American College of Gastroenterology. Published by Elsevier Inc. on behalf of the American College of Gastroenterology.

Abstract:
Despite advances in resuscitative techniques, survival after out‐of‐hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) remains low. Infections, including respiratory tract infections (RTIs), are common complications following OHCA, and antibiotic administration within the first hour of survival has shown some benefit. However, the optimal timing of antibiotic treatment remains uncertain in this population. We aim to evaluate the effect of early antibiotic treatment within the first hour of survival versus late antibiotic treatment after admission on 30‐day mortality and infection rates. The study will be nested in a multicenter randomized controlled trial of OHCA patients with predicted outcome of survival within the first hour of survival (based on Glasgow Coma Scale score, pupillary responses and blood pressure >/= 90 mm Hg), and excluded patients with a clear cause of cardiac arrest such as asphyxia due to cardiac arrest or trauma are randomized to early antibiotic treatment within the first hour of survival or later antibiotic treatment after admission. Our primary outcome is 30‐day mortality and key secondary outcomes are infections rates. We aim to analyze 800 patients in each study arm. This study will provide important data on the timing of antibiotic treatment in OHCA patients with potential benefit due to reduced infections and improved survival in patients treated early.

[STUDY DESIGN] 
Detailed Description
-----------------
AIM: In this study, the investigators hypothesized that psychological resilience has an important role in the prevention of negative health effects associated with stress experienced by health workers. In addition, we hypothesize that narrative group counseling, one of the techniques used in stress management, will be effective in improving psychological resilience among health workers. METHODS: This study is a preliminary study of narrative group counseling for health workers who work night shifts. This will be conducted as a randomised controlled trial with 2 study arms. Participants recruited from among the nursing (n = 50) and healthcare personnel working in the departments of obstetrics and gynecology, neurology, plastic surgery, cardiology, dermatology and hematology at a Turkish state hospital will be randomly assigned to the experimental and control groups at a ratio of 1: 1. Group 1: Experimental group (n = 25) Group 2: Control group (n = 25). Intragroup comparisons will be conducted using paired t-test, Mann Whitney U test and Pearson's chi-square test, and the independent t-test will be used for intergroup comparisons. Data on stress and psychological resilience will be collected before the first, second, third, fourth, fifth, sixth, eighth and tenth group counseling sessions, immediately after the sixth group counseling session, immediately after the end of the study, 1 and 3 months after the completion of the study. DISCUSSION: While the prevalence of psychological distress in the general population varies between 7.4% and 12.7%, this rate is 30% among health workers. Narrative group counseling has been reported to be useful in reducing burnout, improving psychological resilience and improving sleep quality in people from different occupational groups. It is thought that it will have a positive effect on physical and mental health if it is used in health workers.

The interviews will be semi-structured and will follow a standardized protocol. We will use open-ended questions to encourage participants to share their experiences and emotions related to their nursing studies.

The full study arms will include both experimental and control arms. The experimental arm will receive narrative group counseling, while the control arm will receive stress coping interviews in addition to the participants' routine practices.

[inst] 1,4-Dioxane: a new biomarker of 4-Hydroxy-2-Nonenal (4-HNE) adduct formation and oxidative stress in Parkinson's Disease (PD).

Abstract:
Many studies have shown that the 1,4‐Dioxane (1,4‐DOA) is a major protein adduct formed by the oxidation of fatty acids. Mostly it arises from lipid peroxidation and is considered as a marker of oxidative stress. The aim of this study was to evaluate 1,4‐DOA levels in the urine of patients with recent and established Parkinson's disease (PD), in an attempt to test whether it could represent a suitable biomarker of the disease. Subjects enrolled were 30 PD patients, at disease stage III‐IV, 30 in the early stage of Parkinson's disease (PD III‐IV) and 30 healthy volunteers. We used high‐performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) methodologies with fluorescence detection to measure the levels of 1,4‐DOA in their urines. Patients with established PD had significantly higher levels of 1,4‐DOA compared to controls. Significant differences were observed between early PD and those with established PD, suggesting that it could represent a useful marker of the progression of the disease. Furthermore, the levels of 1,4‐DOA correlated positively with the clinical picture of PD. These data were consistent with other studies that have previously shown an association between Parkinson's disease and lipid peroxidation. 1,4‐DOA could represent a new marker of oxidative stress and a possible predictor of disease progression. 1,4‐DOA may be used as a new molecular target for clinical applications.

=================
Acute ischemic stroke is a leading cause of functional disability and mortality worldwide. The current standard of care for stroke treatment is limited to measures aimed at restoring blood flow to the affected area, but often falls short of preventing tissue damage and optimizing patient outcomes. Neurohormonal therapies have recently emerged as a promising area of research in neuroprotection and neurorecovery in stroke patients, potentially offering a new approach to improve patient outcomes by targeting cellular processes involved in neural regeneration, remyelination, and synaptic plasticity.One such potential neurohormonal therapy is ghrelin, a gut-originated hormone that regulates energy homeostasis, inflammation, and neurogenesis. This will be administered by bolus infusion twice daily for five days, in addition to the standard treatment, including intravenous thrombolysis if indicated.

The experimental arm is designed to test the hypothesis that Ghrelin can improve early recovery and long-term functional outcomes in stroke patients undergoing endovascular thrombectomy (EVT). By administering Ghrelin in the first six hours after stroke onset, we aim to assess its potential neuroprotective and neurorestorative effects in this population.

The participant group/arm for the control group will be labeled as "No Intervention: Standard care". This group will consist of patients who will receive standard care for stroke, including intravenous thrombolysis if indicated.

The control group will not receive Ghrelin treatment. Instead, they will be managed according to local practices for the treatment of stroke, including standard care and intravenous thrombolysis if indicated.

The control group serves as a comparison to assess the specific effects of Ghrelin on stroke recovery and functional outcomes. By including a control group, we can evaluate the impact of Ghrelin without confounding factors from other interventions, providing a clearer understanding of its potential benefits.

Study Overview
=================

Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this proposal is to develop a novel clinical application of bioengineered blood-derived products for patients with sickle cell disease. We propose to develop and test a blood-derived product made in our laboratory, from a safe subset of donated blood that cannot be transfused into patients (plasma exchange units). As such, our focus is on the use of a blood derived by-product (ex. stem cells) which cannot be used in patients due to incompatibility. In turn, this will enable a more cost-responsible strategy, as these cells can be isolated from discarded blood products, which would otherwise be destroyed. While other groups are working to find ways to isolate and manipulate stem cells from blood, our proposal is unique in that ours are not stem cells. Instead we propose to isolate and re-use the same specific white blood cells (which are found naturally in large numbers in normal plasma), and isolate these from donated plasma (which is typically discarded). In turn, this will enable a more cost-responsible strategy, as these cells can be isolated from discarded blood products, which would otherwise be destroyed. The investigators propose to test the ability to isolate, culture, and re-infuse these white blood cells, in order to generate additional white blood cells that can be given to sickle cell patients to help prevent and treat sickle cell crises (an unpredictable episode that causes sudden, intense pain). Furthermore, our studies could potentially create a safe source of these cells for use in sickle cell patients.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this proposal is to develop a novel clinical application of bioengineered blood derived products for patients with sickle cell disease. These cell-containing products have been created in vitro by isolating a specific subset of white blood cells (WBC) from a safe subset of donated blood, and then culturing these cells in order to produce more of the same cells, which can be given to sickle cell patients. We will examine the feasibility of isolating, culturing, and infusing these cells in humans. We will test the safety and tolerability of these cells, as a dose-escalating study to test their effect in stimulating healthy hematopoiesis in up

Abstract:
Microtensile fibrin sealant (MTFS) and the new biodegradable fibrin sealant (BDS) were used during gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopic procedures. The success rate and complications related to these techniques were comparable. A total of 108 and 115 patients were enrolled in the studies. For MTFS group, the total rate of complications was 4.7%. For BDS group, this rate was 1.3% which was significantly lower than that for MTFS group. MTFS was associated with the following complications: pain, nausea and vomiting, fever, respiratory infections, bleeding, and emphysema. Among the patients using BDS, there was one minor local infection and one case of nausea and vomiting. Patients using BDS reported significantly higher pain scores at 12, 24, 48 and 96 h postoperatively. Patients using BDS had significantly reduced median length of hospital stay. MTFS and BDS were both effective for achieving hemostasis during endoscopic procedures, BDS may have more advantage in pain management after endoscopic suturing surgery because of its biodegradable and biocompatible properties.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary

This study was designed to investigate that the changes of the immune functional profile between before and after immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy in lung cancer

Detailed Description
-----------------
Non-small cell lung cancer(NSCLC) accounts for more than 80% of lung cancer. More than 20% of patients have PD-L1 positivity. The combination of the two checkpoints CTLA-4 and PD-1 or PD-L1 has become the standard of treatment for advanced NSCLC. Although ICI can have a good efficacy rate and long-term control rate for a small number of patients, however, due to immune-related adverse events (irAEs), its incidence rate is about 75%, and the risk of death from irAEs is about 1% , moreover, 30% of patients can not benefit from the treatment. These patients are still in urgent need of better methods to predict ICI therapy outcomes. In this study, we mainly investigate the changes of the immune functional profile before and after immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy in lung cancer. The results of this study would play a positive role in screening the effect people from the perspective of immunotherapy.

Endoscopic findings are non‐specific, often leading to unnecessary colonoscopies. There is a lack of validated biomarkers and the diagnosis is based mainly on histopathological specimens, often from non‐biopsy proven sites. Colon resection with surgical enterostomosis is the last treatment option in severe cases, however, it is associated with a reduction in quality of life and higher treatment costs. Abstract:
The efficacy of ECP, a specific inhibitor of Abl1 tyrosine kinase, has been evaluated in advanced phase IID myelofibrosis. As a prospective, single arm phase II study, our aim was to evaluate effectiveness of ECP in Japanese patients with post‐polycythemia vera (PPV) myelofibrosis and to describe the toxicity and tolerability seen with this agent. Twenty patients with JAK2 V617F mutation positive PPV myelofibrosis were treated with ECP. Thirteen patients underwent cytoreduction with hydroxyurea, and others did best supportive care (BSC). The median follow‐up was 56 months. Of the 16 evaluable patients, the best response was PR in 14 (87.5%), with four (25.0%) of them having CR. The median duration of PR was not reached. The overall response rate was 93.8% (95% CI: 67.4%‐99.3%). The median time to response was 3.1 months (range, 1.6‐8.0). There was a trend toward response to ECP within the first year of treatment (p = 0.1). There was no significant difference between the hydroxyurea‐treated or BSC‐treated patients regarding all efficacy variables examined. The most common toxicities included nausea (32.1%), fatigue (32.1%), and vomiting (21.7%). There was one treatment‐related Grade 3 QTc prolongation and no Grade 4 adverse events. Conclusion: ECP shows a favorable safety and tolerability profile and an encouraging response rate in Japanese patients with PPV. A randomized controlled trial may be warranted to confirm the results. The randomized controlled trial has been registered at the primary registry (UMIN000004052). 2013 The Japanese Society of Hematology.

Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Extracorporeal photopheresis (ECP) is an established treatment for several autoimmune disorders. The mechanism of action is thought to involve the manipulation of the immune response through the elimination of activated T cells and the induction of regulatory T cells. Recent studies have suggested that ECP may be effective in treating immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI)-induced colitis (ICIcolitis). However, the specific mechanism of action of ECP on the immune cells in the intestinal tract of patients with ICIcolitis is largely unknown. Intestinal biopsies from patients with ICIcolitis undergoing ECP treatment may provide valuable insights into the underlying mechanisms of action and potential biomarkers for monitoring treatment response. Therefore, this pilot study will analyze immune cells in the intestinal tract of patients with ICIcolitis undergoing ECP treatment to determine whether the treatment modifies the immune cell profile and assess the potential for biomarkers.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a pilot study to evaluate whether ECP treatment modifies the immune cell profile in the intestinal tract of patients with ICI colitis. The study will enroll a total of 45 patients with ICI colitis, including 30 patients who are receiving ECP treatment and 15 patients who are not receiving ECP treatment. All patients

The purpose of this study is to test a computer based video game to be played in public places and at home as a means of improving balance and reducing the development of dizziness and falls in the older population. The study will evaluate whether people who have recently experienced dizziness would prefer a game based on physical therapy principles for balancing over a classic computer game played in a similar way. Participants in this study will be recruited from the community by advertisements in senior centers and assisted living and long-term care facilities, and also from the clinics of the participating sites (University of Utah's Aging & Vision Lab and the Cleveland Clinic Dizziness and Balance Disorder Center). These participants will be 60 years of age or older. The subjects must be in good health as determined through a brief history, brief vision test, and brief screen for cognitive function. Participants who are found to have symptoms of balance and/or dizziness will be asked to return to that clinic to complete more extensive balance testing for 15 minutes. Participants will be informed that the purpose of the testing is to help determine whether this video game improves balance. We plan to test 124 participants. Those in Arm 1 will play a computer game based on the popular Nintendo Wii game, Boxing. This game will use a Wii-mote in a manner mimicking common boxing techniques. The game does not require physical activity and is designed to encourage players to stand still. Arm 2 will play a game designed as a more challenging version of Arm 1. However, it will require the player to stand up and balance, rather than to sit in a chair and play. It will also challenge the player physically with arm movements as well as simple punches with the hands. Arm 3 will play the game which is currently marketed for home use by Microsoft called Kinect Adventures. Kinect Adventures is a video game designed to be played without a controller, using the player's movements as a controller. Players use their whole body and arms. This game challenges both the eyes and body to a greater extent than Arm 1 does. The test will be done over the course of a day for approximately four hours. Abstract:
Background: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is one of the leading causes of cancer‐related deaths worldwide. The use of neoadjuvant therapy has been shown to improve outcomes in patients with locally advanced CRC. However, the timing of neoadjuvant therapy is still under debate. This study aims to assess the efficacy of neoadjuvant therapy in patients with locally advanced CRC based on the timing of the treatment. Methods: This was a single‐center retrospective study. We identified patients with locally advanced CRC who received neoadjuvant therapy between January 2013 and June 2018. The patients were divided into two groups based on the timing of neoadjuvant therapy: preoperative (group A) and postoperative (group B) treatment groups. We compared the clinicopathological characteristics, surgical outcomes, and survival outcomes between the two groups. Results: A total of 203 patients with locally advanced CRC were included in the study. The median age was 65 years (IQR 56–71 years), and the median tumor size was 45 mm (IQR 35–64 mm); 54.6% of patients received preoperative neoadjuvant therapy (group A) and 45.4% received postoperative neoadjuvant therapy (group B). There was no significant difference in the clinicopathological characteristics between the two groups. The rates of R0 resection, postoperative morbidity, and mortality were similar between the two groups. The 5‐year overall survival (OS) and disease‐free survival (DFS) rates were also comparable between the two groups (hazard ratio 1.19, 95% confidence interval 0.58–2.42, p=0.592 for OS; hazard ratio 1.66, 95% confidence interval 0.88–3.12, p=0.112 for DFS). Conclusions: The timing of neoadjuvant therapy does not affect the surgical

Abstract:
Background: The SIBTime app is a web‐based application designed to reduce conflict between siblings by helping them manage their time together. This randomized controlled trial aimed to evaluate its effectiveness in reducing conflict between siblings and improving their quality of life. Methods: The trial included 160 parents of children aged 6‐12 years who were randomly assigned to the treatment, active control, and passive control groups. The trial was conducted over an 8‐week period, during which the treatment group used the SIBTime app while the two control groups received the app after 8 weeks of intervention. The primary outcome was sibling conflict, assessed using the CKAS (Conflict between Children and Adolescents Scale) and measured by questionnaires. Secondary outcomes included parents' perceived happiness, satisfaction, and stress, assessed using questionnaires and interviews. Results: The SIBTime app was effective in reducing sibling conflict and improving parents' perceived happiness, satisfaction, and stress. Conclusion: The study highlights the utility of the SIBTime app in managing sibling conflict and promoting family harmony.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The SIBTime app will be used in an 8-week intervention to test its relevance, acceptability, cultural appropriateness, and potential efficacy. In addition to traditional assessments of effectiveness and acceptability, we will also be using qualitative methods to capture parental perceptions of engagement with the app and the barriers and facilitators to use.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This study uses a hybrid mixed methods approach in which parallel quantitative and qualitative arms will be used to examine the preliminary efficacy of a web application tool, SIBTime, with a treatment group of parent-child dyads. After reviewing the literature and reviewing existing assessment and treatment options, the SIBTime tool was specifically designed to target two common outcomes associated with having a child with a disability: decreased caregiver burden and increased caregiver resilience (both psychosocial). SIBTime is both mobile and web-based, and it leverages modern technology to provide caregivers with a tool that addresses the specific challenges they encounter in caring for a child with a disability and the resilience-related factors that could help them cope more effectively with their situation. SIBTime uses a three-pronged approach to provide caregivers with specific support and education in three distinct domains: coping skills education (i.e., behavioral strategies for managing challenging behaviors), self-care education (i.e., education about the mental health and wellness needs of caregivers), and peer support through a social networking platform that enables anonymous connection with other caregivers of children with disabilities. We also incorporate motivational interviewing (MI) principles within the app to engage users and foster sustainable behavior change. MI principles serve as a foundation for the app and provide an evidence-based approach to guide interactions between the app and its users.

Official Title
-----------------
The Long-term Impact of SIBTime™ Version 2.0 on the Well-being of Australian Caregivers: The SIBTime Study

Abstract:
Background and Aims: Infections caused by fungal pathogens are often difficult to treat with limited therapeutic options. In the current study, we aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy and safety of FV471 for the treatment of patients with fungal pulmonary, pulmonary aspergillosis (IFA), mucormycosis (MO), fusariosis (FUS), and deep, persistent, or recurrent endemic mycoses. Methods: In a Phase 3 trial, 234 patients with fungal pulmonary mycoses treated with FV471 (184 patients) or placebo (50 patients) were followed up for at least 12 weeks or until death or end of treatment. The primary study objective was to evaluate the clinical success, which included a composite endpoint of death from any cause or discharge with any improvement in respiratory symptoms (improvement in dyspnea, infiltrates, fever and/or weight loss). Clinical success with FV471 was 76% with a hazard ratio of 2.45 (p<0.0001) compared to placebo. Clinical failure with FV471 was 24% with a hazard ratio of 0.36 (p=0.003). Safety was assessed by collecting patient data for 72 weeks or until death from any cause, whichever occurred first. Conclusions: These results demonstrate that FV471 has a significantly lower incidence of all‐cause mortality and clinical failure compared to placebo and is safe in the treatment of patients with pulmonary fungus infections. Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: We examined the effect of a home‐based exercise and education program on functional performance, functional capacity, perceived exertion, and functional health status of community‐dwelling older adults. METHODS: Two hundred and seventy ambulatory, community‐dwelling older adults (mean age: 76.9 years, 60.7% women) with at least 2 functional limitations were recruited and randomly allocated to exercise and education (treatment, n = 105), self‐paced walking (control, n = 105) or their usual care activities (usual care, n = 67). The exercise and education groups participated in standardized, individually tailored, home‐based exercises and education activities for 6 months. We used intention‐to‐treat analysis. Functional performance (Functional Independence Measure (FIM) scale score), functional capacity (self‐paced walking) were assessed every 3 months for 1 year, perceived exertion was assessed every 3 months for 6 months and functional health status (SF‐36/Short Form‐36) was assessed at baseline and after 6 months. The change in these outcomes were compared between groups using Generalized Linear Mixed Models. RESULTS: A significant main effect over time was observed for the total FIM score, 6‐minute walking distance, and perceived exertion. There were also significant interaction effects on the total FIM score and perceived exertion. Significant treatment differences over time were observed, with the exercise and education group having a greater increase in the total FIM score and lower perceived exertion score than the usual‐care group at 6 months. There were no significant treatment differences in self‐paced walking distance over time. There was no significant main effect over time on functional health status. CONCLUSION: The results showed benefits of a home‐based exercise and education program on functional performance and perceived exertion, but not functional capacity and functional health status after 6 months among older adults with functional limitations.

Introduction
Physical function decline and physical inactivity are major factors contributing to loss of independent living among older adults

Scientific title
=================
Adaptive Radiotherapy of Breast Cancer With Ultrathin Multi-Leaf Collimator in Hypersensitive Patients Based on Intensity-modulated Radiotherapy (IMRT) Technology

Plain English Summary
=================
Background and study aimsThe incidence of breast cancer continues to rise, posing a significant healthcare burden. IMRT technology has become the mainstay of radiotherapy for breast cancer, but for patients with hypersensitivity, IMRT radiotherapy can cause significant skin and chest wall toxicity. The ETHOS system is an advanced IMRT device that enables ultrathin multi-leaf collimators (MLCs) and superior dose conformity, thus reducing toxicity. However, ultrathin MLCs can produce artifacts during the planning process, limiting their clinical application. To address these challenges, the study team proposed to use ultrathin MLCs with adaptive radiotherapy (ART) techniques to further improve the effectiveness and safety of IMRT treatment.The primary aim of the study is to assess the effectiveness of ART with ultrathin MLCs in reducing the incidence of dermatitis and other side effects. In addition, the researchers aim to evaluate the feasibility of ART with ultrathin MLCs, as well as the impact on the clinical outcomes of patients treated with this technique.Who can participate?Patients with stage I-III breast cancer undergoing IMRT radiotherapy with good treatment compliance, who meet the following conditions will be included in the study: (1) women aged 18-75, (2) ECOG score <= 2, (3) no history of radiotherapy

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The study hypothesis is that a comprehensive, multimodal rehabilitation program is feasible post CABG.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The rationale of the current proposal is that peri- or post-operative rehabilitation plays a vital role in functional status, quality of life, and mortality in patients with cardiovascular disease. In the United States alone, coronary artery disease (CAD) afflicts over 9.5 million people. CABG, or coronary artery bypass grafting, is the most commonly performed heart surgery in the United States. Yet, post-CABG rehabilitation is significantly underutilized. Patients who undergo CABG are at high risk of developing heart failure and post-operative depression and are subject to chronic pain. These factors have been associated with poor functional status, quality of life, and outcomes. Several studies have shown that pre-operative exercise can improve both function and outcomes in cardiac patients undergoing CABG. Unfortunately, many cardiac patients do not receive pre-operative physical therapy. In addition, 1 out of 5 patients are readmitted within 30 days and most patients do not initiate a post-operative rehabilitation program after hospital discharge. The investigators have recently been funded by the NHLBI (R03HL105604) to conduct a clinical trial studying the effects of physical therapy, nutritional counseling, and heart health education (Phase 1) as adjunctive therapy prior to CABG (n=20) and comparing the results of this program to an optimized post-CABG therapy program (Phase 2). The current study (Phase 3) proposes to build on the results of Phase 1 and phase 2, and test the feasibility a clinical trial to evaluate the impact of a comprehensive, multimodal rehabilitation program with the goal of implementing the study intervention in a large, multi-center clinical trial to test its efficacy.

Official Title
-----------------
A Randomized Control Trial of Physical Performance (EXER) and Exercise Tolerance (EXTE) Comparing Pre and Post

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Allergic diseases have reached epidemic levels worldwide, with a significant impact on health and quality of life. Dupilumab is a monoclonal antibody that blocks the shared receptor subunit of interleukin (IL)‐4 and IL‐13, which are key cytokines involved in the inflammatory response associated with allergies. This study aims to investigate the therapeutic potential of dupilumab in allergic disease in humans, using asthma as a model system.METHODS: A randomized, controlled, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled clinical trial will be performed in healthy participants aged 18‐65 years with a history of asthma, with specific sensitivity for house dust mites. On the basis of methacholine challenge and blood eosinophil counts, participants will be stratified to undergo aeroallergen challenge with increasing concentrations of house dust mites while receiving either dupilumab or placebo. The primary outcome will be the change in asthma symptoms during acute exposure to house dust mites.Secondary outcomes will include airway hyperresponsiveness, airway inflammation, and quality of life measures related to asthma. The study will enroll 64 subjects.RESULTS: The results of the study are expected to shed light on the role of dupilumab in allergic disease and its potential clinical utility in treating this condition. By understanding the mechanisms underlying its therapeutic effect, the findings may lead to new therapies for allergies, which are currently a major public health concern.CONCLUSION: The planned study constitutes a phase I trial with a placebo control of a novel treatment for allergic disease. Its results may help further our understanding of allergies and potentially lead to safer and more effective treatments.

The primary efficacy outcome measure is the complete pathological response rate, defined as the absence of viable tumor cells in the surgical specimen after neoadjuvant therapy. Secondary efficacy outcome measures include the objective response rate, progression-free survival, overall survival, and disease-free survival. We will also evaluate the pharmacokinetics and immunogenicity of the treatment regimen.

The use of multiple types of imaging, including CT scans, PET-CT scans, and EUS-guided biopsy, ensures that we have a comprehensive assessment of the disease status and response to therapy.
