Abstract:
Background/Aims: The therapeutic effect of chemoradiotherapy combined with first‐line chemotherapy for non‐small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is limited, and it’s often difficult to improve patients' prognosis and quality of life. Methods: The study was approved by the ethics committee and conducted by the Affiliated Hospital of Guilin Medical University and randomized. Patients were randomly divided into three groups, the first group received concurrent chemoradiotherapy, the second was treated with chemoradiotherapy and immunotherapy, and the third was treated with combination of chemotherapy, immunotherapy, and adjuvant chemotherapy. The evaluation indexes included tumor volume, tumor volume, tumor volume, PET‐CT evaluation, and long‐term survival. Results: Compared with the control group, the efficacy of the chemoradiotherapy control group was better than that of the other two groups in the treatment of patients with stage IV disease who underwent postoperative radiotherapy alone. The chemoradiotherapy control group had a significantly better long‐term survival rate than that of the other two groups. It is considered that the postoperative tumor volume has prognostic significance for the prognosis of patients with advanced lung cancer. Conclusion: The study found that chemoradiotherapy combined with adjuvant immunotherapy had better efficacy in prolonging the survival

Study Arms:
- Experimental: Neoadjuvant Therapy With Toripalimab and JS004 Combined With Etoposide and Platinum Chemotherapy
In this arm, 30 patients with limited-stage small cell lung cancer will receive 4 cycles of neoadjuvant Toripalimab and JS004 combined with Etoposide and Platinum chemotherapy. Patients with resectable tumors after neoadjuvant therapy will undergo surgery. Postoperative patients will receive two cycles of Toripalimab and JS004 combined with Etoposide and Platinum chemotherapy. Finally, all patients will receive maintenance treatment with Toripalimab and JS004 until disease progression.

Abstract
=================

Background
-----------------
Skin cancer is a common form of cancer that can have devastating consequences for patients and society. It is estimated that approximately 5 million cases of non-melanoma skin cancer are diagnosed in the United States each year, making it the most common form of cancer in the country. While sun protection is crucial in preventing skin cancer, the efficacy of sunscreens in real-world conditions is often compromised by factors such as water immersion, sweating, and perspiration. Long-wear sunscreens containing metal oxide particles have been developed to address these challenges. Sunscreen -R43 is a newly developed long-wear sunscreen that contains titanium dioxide and zinc oxide as its active ingredients. This study aims to evaluate the water resistance of Suncreen -R43 by assessing its SPF values in static conditions and after 80 minutes of water immersion. This will be done using the erythema method. The study also aims to assess the influence of repeated application of Sunscreen -R43 on the incidence of skin cancer and the percentage of SBCs (Sunburn Cells) in the skin. The study will be a randomized, controlled, double-blind trial involving healthy male and female individuals aged 18 to 60 years. Participants will be randomized into two groups: Experimental and Control. The Experimental group will undergo SPF evaluation both in static conditions and after 80 minutes of water imm

One hundred patients with osteoarthritis of the hip were randomized to receive daily 1 g supplementation of either omega-3 (n = 50) or placebo (n = 50) for 12 months in addition to basic pain management. Outcome measures included pain at rest, on activity, and during nighttime assessed with a visual analogue scale; joint function assessed with the Harris hip score (HHS) at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months; and adverse events. 16 patients discontinued the study (n = 7 in the omega-3 group and 9 in the placebo group) during the study due to adverse events or other reasons, while adverse events also resulted in discontinuation of supplementation in 1 patient in each group. 23 patients had died from non-study-related causes by the time of final analysis. The supplementation with omega-3 had no effect on either pain (p > 0.10) or on HHS (p > 0.72). There were two adverse events possibly related to study drug. The omega-3 intervention may not have been adequate to attenuate the symptoms of patients with osteoarthritis of the hip. Additional studies, utilizing larger doses of omega-3, are necessary in order to determine the potential therapeutic effect of omega-3. 2013 Informa UK Ltd.

Our team has designed this study with the goal of testing the efficacy of a more comprehensive behavioral intervention in promoting consistent HIV testing and promoting the intention to uptake pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) and post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) compared to a didactic intervention. The rationale behind this design is that we believe that a comprehensive behavioral intervention that focuses on various aspects related to consistent HIV testing, harm reduction, mental health well-being, sexual empowerment and self-care can have a greater impact on promoting positive health behavior and outcomes than a didactic intervention. By providing access to HIV self-test kits every three months, which is recommended by national and international guidelines, we hope to increase screening for HIV and other sexually transmitted infections (STIs), ultimately reducing HIV and STI transmission.

Prospective controlled study

Description
=================
Interobserver reliability is a crucial aspect of medical diagnosis, particularly in the field of rheumatology, where accurate diagnosis can impact treatment plans and patient outcomes. The assessment of interobserver reliability in the diagnosis of fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS) is of particular importance because the clinical criteria for diagnosis are subjective and may vary depending on the expertise and experience of the clinician. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the interobserver reliability between two rheumatologists in the diagnosis of FMS, using a questionnaire developed to assess the presence of pain and stiffness.The study design was a prospective controlled study. Two independent rheumatologists, with at least 5 years of clinical experience, each evaluated 50 patients diagnosed with FMS using the same diagnostic criteria. 
The rheumatologists were blinded to the diagnosis of the other physician. Patients were identified through the rheumatology clinic at a university hospital. The patients were excluded if they had a diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis, lupus, or any other autoimmune disease. 
The rheumatologists were asked to fill out a questionnaire assessing 18 tender points and 9 pain points. The questionnaire consisted of a grid that included the location of each pain and stiffness point, with yes/no questions to assess whether the point was present or not. The questionnaire also included sections for demographic information and current medications. 
The interobserver reliability was assessed using the kappa statistic, which is a simple measure of agreement between two judges and can range from 0 (no agreement) to 1 (perfect agreement). In this study, a kappa value of 0.6 or higher was considered to indicate acceptable interobserver reliability. The study results were tabulated and analyzed using the kappa statistic, and a p-value of 0.05 or less was considered statistically significant.

Inclusion criteria
=================
1. Diagnosis of fibromyalgia syndrome;
2. Aged of older than 18 years;
3. The patient can read and understand the questionnaire;
4. Available for a follow-up visit to the hospital.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Osteoporotic vertebral deformities (also known as fractures) represent a major public health challenge and are an essential health problem in Brazil and other developed and developing countries. Patients with osteoporotic vertebral compression fractures experience significant pain and functional limitations, in addition to increased mortality, morbidity, and associated fractures. NICE guidelines (2016) and NHS evidence (2019) recommend that kyphoplasty should be available to patients with osteoporotic vertebral compression fractures without neurological compression and with the presence of severe acute pain. A literature review has shown that kyphoplasty is a safe and well-accepted therapy. However, in some cases, patients may require an alternative approach. The objective of this pilot study is to assess the effectiveness and outcomes of treatments with porous titanium microspheres compared with treatments of kyphoplasty using different types of material (alternative) from patients in emergency osteoporotic vertebrae fractures without neurological compression, presenting severe acute pain. This will be a randomized pilot study with three arms: arms 1 and 2 will be treatments with kyphoplasty with porous trabecular titanium microspheres; and arm 3 will be kyphoplasty with different materials for kyphoplasty (alternative).

Comparative Effectiveness Efficacy of Porous Trabecular Titanium Microspheres (Porous Cells) in Kyphoplasty for Treating Osteoporotic Fractures of the Vertebral Body Without Neurological Compression in Patients in Emergency

Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) with tumor deposits (TD) is a distinct subtype of PTC, which was introduced by Ota et al in 2017. The pathological features of PTC with TD include small and round tumor cells with a high proliferative rate, and extensive involvement of the lymphatic system along with extracapsular invasion of central or lateral lymph nodes. Several studies reported that PTC with TD is associated with a poor prognosis. However, the prognostic value of TD has not been widely recognized, mainly due to the lack of evidence. This study will be a retrospective cohort study, aiming to compare the characteristics of tumor deposits in PTC and the pathological behaviors between patients with and without tumor deposits. We will also investigate the prognostic value of tumor deposits in PTC patients.

Abstract:
Background: Patients and society should be informed about pain science as this information helps alleviate their misunderstanding of chronic pain. Objectives: We aimed to assess the effectiveness of a pain science education conference for students majoring in medicine and dentistry. Methods: This study was a one‐group pre‐post design with a delayed control group for students who did not participate in the conference; the latter did so only at the University of the Basque Country. All participants filled in the Spanish adaptation of the Understanding Pain Questionnaire (UPQ‐2) before and after the conference. Paired t‐tests were used to assess the changes in the UPQ‐2 score. The effects of the questionnaire were compared with those of self‐perceived pain knowledge using the Kruskal‐Wallis H test. Results: The participants' global pain knowledge increased significantly (UPQ‐2 ≥ 45) after attending the conference. Furthermore, those who passed the pain science pre‐test (UPQ‐2 ≥ 54) exhibited significant increases in global pain knowledge and pain science knowledge in the main pain areas (UPQ ≥ 54) after participating in the conference. Conclusions: This pain science education conference was effective for all students and promoted significant improvements in their pain science knowledge. Students who received better scores on the pre‐test required a better understanding of the different pain domains and areas.

1. Introduction
The understanding of chronic pain is a priority research area globally; patients are commonly misinformed about the biological and psychosocial mechanisms underlying it . Patients’ lack of understanding of pain is a significant barrier to pain management, which can contribute to fear, disability, and stigmatization . In fact, studies show that patients with pain and related conditions are poorly equipped to cope with changes in their pain status and often lack useful knowledge about pain . Patients might develop misconceptions about pain that may lead them to exaggerate the severity of their symptoms . In contrast, patients who are well versed in the concept of pain (e.g., its mechanism, causes, and treatment) are likely to be active in managing their pain and recovering to their previous level of function .
Due to its interprofessional nature, chronic or recurrent pain affects various health professions, including medicine and dentistry. In Spain, the prevalence of chronic pain in dental clinics is

The choice of these medications is based on data demonstrating that each acts on one of the three major systems that modulate blood pressure. The 3-Drug combination was chosen because of the availability and low cost of these medicines and because data from multiple large clinical trials have demonstrated the safety of these drugs.

Hydrochlorothiazide is a diuretic (lowers blood pressure in part by reducing the volume of blood in circulation.

Amlodipine, a calcium-channel blocker, lowers blood pressure by slowing down the heart and dilating blood vessels.

Lozazepam, a vasodilator, lowers the blood pressure at the heart level by opening the arteries.

Abstract:
Background: Psoriasis vulgaris is the most common type of psoriasis, resulting in significant physical, emotional, and social distress. The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of etanercept in the treatment of psoriasis vulgaris. Methods: A total of 30 patients with psoriasis vulgaris were enrolled in the study and randomly assigned to two groups: the etanercept group and the placebo group. The etanercept group received etanercept 50 mg twice weekly for 12 weeks, while the placebo group received a placebo twice weekly for 12 weeks. The primary outcomes were the proportion of patients achieving at least 75% improvement in the Psoriasis Area and Severity Index (PASI 75) and the proportion of patients with a decrease of at least two points on the Dermatology Life Quality Index (DLQI). Results: After 12 weeks of treatment, the etanercept group had significantly greater improvements in the PASI (p<0.001) and DLQI (p<0.001) scores compared to the placebo group. The rates of adverse events were similar between the two groups. Conclusion: Etanercept is an effective and safe treatment option for psoriasis vulgaris.

Certainly! In the Experimental: Active tDCS arm, participants will undergo five in-person visits in Week 1 for the administration of active transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS). From Weeks 2 to 9, they will receive weekly active tDCS sessions preceding the scheduled yoga sessions. The tDCS sessions will involve the administration of a constant anodal current of 2 mA for 20 minutes, targeting the primary motor cortex contralateral to the most painful site. The yoga program will be led by a certified instructor and will consist of centring, warming up, yoga postures, and guided relaxation.

In the Sham Comparator: Sham tDCS arm, participants will attend five in-person visits in Week 1 for the administration of sham transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS). From Weeks 2 to 9, they will receive weekly sham tDCS sessions before the scheduled yoga sessions. The sham tDCS sessions will mimic the sensation of current without actual stimulation. Participants will also participate in the same yoga program led by a certified instructor.

The study is designed to evaluate the effect of the transient neurostimulation device on the sensory and motor responses of human muscles to pain induced by a needle. The test equipment is a transcutaneous electrode needle, and the test material is a needle with an electric stimulation device. The test material does not contain drugs.The participant will not feel pain, and will only feel vibration, as the vibration of the electrode has no effect on the participant. The device was developed using a 12.4mm, 27 gauge venous needle with 4 electrodes (5mm length, 3.2mm width, and 4mm spacing) fixed at both the tip and flank. The device is equipped with a single channel, monopolar neurostimulator capable of generating low-frequency (2Hz) trains of 300-microsec pulses at an output current of 5-15mA.The study will utilize a single-arm approach, with the investigational TES/ES needle being inserted into a limb or joint prior to skin puncture. The stimulator will be set to pulse 15 micro-seconds wide, at 5 milliamps (mA) and/or 30 milliamps (mA), at a frequency of 2 hertz (Hz). Participants will be asked to rate their discomfort on a 0-100 scale, with 0 representing no discomfort and 100 representing the most severe pain imaginable. They will also be asked to rate the degree of muscular contraction on a scale of 0 to 100, with 0 representing no contraction and 100 representing maximal contraction.The investigator will record the subject's baseline response (sensory response and motor response) as a "before" reading and the response after stimulation as a "after" reading. If the participant is unable to fully describe the pain, the pain level will be measured at 0, 50, or 100, with 0 representing the least unpleasant pain and 100 representing the

Abstract:
AIM: To investigate the incidence and risk factors of postoperative complications and delayed gastric emptying (DGE) in elderly patients with malignant gastric tumor. METHODS: Between January 2014 and December 2017, 308 elderly patients with malignant gastric tumor were admitted to our hospital and divided into a younger group (<70 years old) and an older group (≥70 years old). The incidence of postoperative complications was analysed. The risk factors of postoperative complications and DGE in these patients were investigated. RESULTS: In total, 241 postoperative complications occurred in these patients. The incidence of postoperative complications and DGE in the younger group was 123/160 (76.9%) and 47/160 (29.4%), respectively. The corresponding incidence of patients aged ≥70 years was 86/148 (58.0%) and 31/148 (20.9%), respectively. The incidence of postoperative complications and DGE in the older group was lower than that in the younger group in both univariate and multivariate analysis. Multivariate Cox proportional regression hazards analysis showed that age and histology were independent risk factors for DGE and postoperative complications in elderly patients with malignant gastric tumor. Abstract:
Many elderly patients develop myalgias and paresthesias after being treated with ropinirole. These symptoms may be related to the pharmacological characteristics and potency of ropinirole. In this report, the clinical characteristics of patients with these adverse effects were investigated to identify the risk factors. We retrospectively compared 107 patients with these symptoms and 102 patients without symptoms. The former patients received mean daily doses between 2.4 and 11.2 mg/day at the onset of symptoms. Symptoms developed during treatment with a mean daily dose of 3.9 mg/day. The mean dose at the onset of symptoms was significantly lower in the former patients than in the latter ones (1.3 vs. 4.2 mg/day; P < 0.001). There was no significant difference between these groups in the mean daily dose of dopamine agonist on the day the symptoms developed. All the former patients suffered from paresthesias. Myalgias tended to be accompanied by paresthesias in these patients. All the former patients reported that their symptoms developed soon after treatment with ropinirole and that there were no prodromal symptoms. There was no significant difference between these groups in motor scores. There was no significant difference between these groups in the age, sex or mean duration of Parkinson's disease. However, the prevalence of postural hypotension and orthostatic symptoms, and the dose of antihypertensive medication, were significantly lower in the former patients than in the latter ones. We conclude that our results indicate that the adverse effects induced by ropinirole may be related to the patients' age, treatment regimen and presence of postural hypotension and orthostatic symptoms. Therefore, elderly patients with postural hypotension should be carefully watched. In addition, we recommend that the dosage should be titrated as slowly as possible and that it should be stopped immediately if adverse effects develop.

The study aims to explore the pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and safety of itepekimab given as a single intravenous (IV) dose in healthy participants and participants with non-cystic fibrosis bronchiectasis.

Three different single dose levels of itepekimab will be investigated: 1mg/kg, 10mg/kg, and 40mg/kg. The dose levels will be escalated at the discretion of the investigators in response to data from previous dose level cohorts. Participants may receive itepekimab intravenously every 4 or 12 weeks. The duration of the study will vary depending on the participant's group. Participants in Groups 7 and 8 may be enrolled to an open-label extension study. Participants in the open-label extension study will continue to receive itepekimab until discontinuation of the study due to withdrawal of consent or other reasons.

The pharmacokinetics will be assessed by the use of validated bioanalytical method based on protein assay (by human enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA in vitro method). Abstract:
INTRODUCTION ‐ A significant number of acute and chronic conditions are linked to high rates of myocardial injury and death in people with heart failure (HF). Thus, there is a need to find new therapeutic targets or interventions for the management of myocardial injury. Our group discovered that inhibition or genetic deletion of the glucose transporter GLUT1 (GLUT1) reduces myocardial ischemic and reperfusion injury in mice. Since that observation, GLUT1 has been shown to play a role in mediating stress‐induced hypertrophy and oxidative stress as well as renal function. The aim of this study is to evaluate the role of the GLUT1 in the heart failure pathophysiology, and to test the therapeutic potential of the GLUT1 inhibitor, GLUT14, for the treatment of chronic HF. It is expected that treating HF patients with GLUT14 will lead to improvement in LV systolic function and LV diastolic function as well as reduced fibrosis. METHODS AND ANALYSIS ‐ This is a double‐blinded, placebo‐controlled, multicenter parallel group phase II trial involving 15 European centers. About 90 adults with HF, NYHA class II‐III, left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) 45‐55%, and who are on optimal HF therapy, will be randomized to 12 weeks of GLUT14 250 mg/day or matched placebo. The primary outcome is change in LVEF at 12 weeks, using CMR imaging. Echocardiography as secondary endpoint, and serum creatinine as explorative endpoint will also be assessed. A total of 80 patients (40 per arm) will be needed for 80% power to detect a 5% absolute difference in LVEF, and allow for a 20% drop‐out rate. The significance level will be set at two‐tailed α=0.05.ETHICS AND DISSEMINATION ‐ We have received local institutional approvals from relevant ethics committees and national and/or regulatory agencies

The objective of this study was to compare the effects of two doses of intratympanic dexamethasone on outcomes of sensorineural hearing loss caused by sudden idiopathic sensorineural hearing loss (S.I.S.H.L.). Design: Randomized clinical trial Setting: A university‐affiliated university hospital Participants: Patients with S.I.S.H.L who were not ameliorated after a 3‐week treatment with systemic steroids. The exclusion criteria were: presence of any middle ear or inner ear disease, history of prior ear surgery, or a history of middle ear trauma of the affected ear. Interventions: 4 mg of intratympanic dexamethasone was injected into the middle ear through the tympanic membrane for four consecutive weeks. (Group 1: 1 mg/ml dexamethasone. Group 2: 2 mg/ml dexamethasone. Group 3: 1 mg/ml dexamethasone with gentamicin . Group 4: 3 ml/ml normal saline). The outcomes of this study were hearing recovery (15 dB or more), hearing improvement (>5 dB), and the difference of the thresholds between 2 years after the treatment and the initial threshold. The results of hearing recovery and improvement were analyzed using chi square or fisher exact probability tests, and the difference of the thresholds between 2 years after the treatment and the initial threshold was analyzed using the paired t‐test. For all tests, p values under 0.05 were considered statistically significant. The hearing thresholds at both ears of all participants were within the normal or mild hearing loss range before enrollment. Minimally Invasive Hip Resurfacing

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the clinical and radiographic outcomes of patients undergoing anterior primary total hip arthroplasty (THA) and posterior primary THA when a novel minimally invasive (MIS) approach is used. The novel MIS approach is based on a less invasive approach to the gluteus maximum (GMax), a minimally invasive approach to approach to the hip capsule, and a modified surgical procedure to implant the hip components. The investigators believe that this combination of factors is important for good patient outcomes. The investigators propose to assess clinical and radiographic outcomes of this approach in patients undergoing THA for end-stage arthritis utilizing two groups. The study group will be comprised of 100 patients undergoing minimally invasive hip resurfacing (MIS-HR) with the ObsID-GMax system. A historical cohort of patients having a conventional posterior approach to primary THA at the same institution for end-stage hip arthritis will be used as direct comparators (Post Control, n=100). The investigators will compare patient outcomes at 1, 3 and12 postoperatively for the MIS Group versus the Post Control Group. The investigators hypothesize that minimally invasive hip resurfacing technique will result in comparable outcomes as posterior primary THA. The investigators also expect no difference in postoperative outcomes between the minimally invasive and posterior approach in this population.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The investigators propose to assess clinical and radiographic outcomes in patients undergoing THA for end-stage arthritis utilizing two groups.        - The catheter ablation (with a CE [Conformité Européenne] marked device) is the key specified technique for performing pulmonary vein isolation in the ablation arm in this trial. This allows the physician electrophysiologist to perform a circumferential ablation around the pulmonary veins to electrically isolate the vein, thus preventing pulmonary vein ectopy from triggering AF.
     - Procedure: DC Cardioversion
       - DC cardioversion (DCCV) is used to treat irregular heart rhythms (commonly atrial fibrillation). The procedure involves sedation or anesthesia and placement of electrodes on the chest. An electrical impulse is passed across the electrodes to return the heart rhythm to normal.

Objective: Based on the results of a phase I study, this study aimed to investigate the effect of tadalafil and an endothelial repairing peptide on the clinical characteristics, circulatory concentrations, and urinary excretion of soluble c‐terminal VWA domain containing protein A (svPSEL‐5) in men undergoing intravitreal aflibercept treatment

Background: Tadalafil improves vasodilation in men with vasoreactive ED, and administration to ED patients has been shown to decrease plasma levels of intercellular adhesion molecule‐1 and leukocyte‐endothelial adhesion molecule-1. Endothelial repairing peptides (ERPs) are components of the body’s inflammatory reaction that have been shown to improve the clinical characteristics and outcomes of PDR patients by controlling the inflammatory response. The purpose of this study is to investigate the effects of tadalafil on the clinical characteristics, serum concentrations, and urinary excretion of svPSEL‐5 in men with PDR and vasoreactive ED who receive intravitreal anti-VEGF treatment

This study aims to evaluate the safety and tolerability of the study drug, OLU-CAR-T, in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage 3-5. The study will involve a total of 60 patients, who will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: a standard dose arm, a low dose arm, and a mid-dose arm. The study will last for a duration of 22 weeks, during which the patients will receive 12 weeks of treatment with the study drug followed by 10 weeks of follow-up. The primary outcome measure will be the change in estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) from baseline to 12 weeks, while the secondary outcome measures will include changes in kidney function, blood pressure, and urinary biomarkers. Overall, this study will provide important safety and tolerability data for OLU-CAR-T in patients with CKD stage 3-5.

Abstract
=================

Background
-----------------
Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a rare and potentially life-threatening pulmonary condition characterized by elevated pulmonary vascular resistance, leading to right ventricular failure and ultimately death. The diagnostic yield of the current methods for identifying patients with PAH is limited, and new methods are needed to improve outcomes for patients. Preliminary studies have suggested that preimplantation genetic diagnosis (PGD) techniques can be used to detect PAH in embryos, potentially allowing for the selection of embryos that are free from the disease. In this study, the investigators will develop and validate a PGD protocol for the detection of PAH in patients undergoing IVF treatment. The study will be conducted on patients with suspected PAH who have been referred for genetic testing. PGD will be performed to identify clinically significant genetic variants associated with PAH, and the results of the PGD assay will be compared to the current diagnostic methods. If the PGD assay is successful, the investigators will conduct a randomized controlled trial to evaluate the impact of PGD on pregnancy outcomes in patients with suspected PAH.
-----------------
To develop and validate a PGD protocol for the detection of clinically significant genetic variants associated with PAH in patients undergoing IVF treatment.

Intervention
-----------------
In the laboratory phase, the investigators will develop and validate a PGD assay using a cohort of patients with suspected PAH. PGD will be performed using a targeted sequencing approach, which involves sequencing the DNA of selected genes known to be associated with PAH. The investigators will also conduct a retrospective analysis of previous genetic testing data from patients with suspected PAH to identify clinically significant genetic variants that were not detected using the current diagnostic methods. In the clinical phase, the investigators will enroll patients with suspected PAH

1,040 patients with obstructive sleep apnea and pharyngeal muscle collapse in the velopharyngeal area/retropalatal will be recruited. They will undergo flexible nasolaryngoscopy by an expert otolaryngologist to determine their condition. Patients with the most severe level of snoring intensity and frequency, as defined by a questionnaire (Berlin Questionnaire, Epworth Sleepiness Scale) and the diagnosis of pharyngeal muscle collapse, will be selected for the study. The subjects will be divided into two groups and randomly assigned. Each group will be given a total of 12 therapy sessions (2 times per week for 6 weeks). Both groups will perform myofunctional therapy exercises twice a day for 20 minutes each time from Monday to Friday for 6 weeks, with Saturday and Sunday reserved as rest days. After 6 weeks, patients in the experimental group will be evaluated for palatopharyngeus, palatoglossus, uvula, tensor veli palatine, and levator veli palatine muscles with an ultrasonography examination by a radiologist. They will then undergo an overnight polysomnogram and a flexible nasolaryngoscopy.

interventions: myofunctional therapy exercise, no intervention, and behavioral therapy exercise. The intervention group will receive myofunctional therapy exercise, including vocal letters, tongue exercises, face exercises, and icing. They will perform these exercises twice a day for 20 minutes every day for 6 weeks. Compliance will be monitored through exercise logs, video submissions, and weekly evaluations by the doctor. The control group will be given no specific intervention and will not receive any exercises or instructions. The behavioral therapy exercise group will receive instructions on how to regulate their sleep and dietary habits to reduce snoring. This group will be given information on sleep deprivation, poor sleep hygiene, excessive alcohol consumption, and high-calorie diets. They will be asked to refrain from snoring triggers such as alcohol, smoking, and caffeine and to adopt healthy sleep habits such as establishing a regular sleep schedule, avoiding caffeine and alcohol before bedtime, and maintaining a comfortable sleeping environment. They will be encouraged to modify their diet by reducing calorie intake, avoiding late-night meals, and choosing healthy snacks. They will also be advised to maintain an active lifestyle and engage in regular exercise. The impact of the intervention will be evaluated through flexible nasolaryngoscopy, Epworth Sleepiness Scale questionnaire, and Berlin questionnaire to measure snoring intensity and frequency before and after the 12-week training period. The impact of the control group and behavioral therapy exercise group will be evaluated to compare the effectiveness of myofunctional therapy exercise. The study intends to provide evidence-based data on the effectiveness of myofunctional therapy exercise in reducing snoring and pharyngeal muscle collapse in adults with a high risk of obstructive sleep apnea. This will help healthcare professionals and patients make informed decisions about potentially effective interventions for reducing snoring and pharyngeal muscle collapse.

Snoring and Sleep Apnea Syndrome

Intervention
=================
Intervention consists in the practice of myofunctional exercises for 20 minutes at an interval from the age of 18 to 65 years. Myofunctional therapy exercise is based on the exercises of the myofunctional therapist Raul Gonzalez, who proposes the activation of the facial muscles responsible for the opening, closing, elevation and depression of the lips (Oral), the elevation and opening of the palate (palatal) and the strengthening of the soft palate, tongue, face and hypopharynx (pharyngeal), the activation of the tongue and its position between the teeth during swallowing, the control of the muscles to produce the correct pressure, position and airflow in the mouth for breathing and eating, the correct position of the lips and tongue during swallowing, the correct position of the teeth in the mouth, the activation of the hypopharyngeal sphincter to close the airway, the control of mouth breathing, and the normalization of oral posture.

Drug

Epworth Sleepiness Scale (ESS) measured before and after treatment

Mallampati's scoring system measured before and after treatment;
The Berlin-Questionnaire measured before and after treatment;
Rhinoscopy measured before and after treatment;

2. Snoring and pharyngeal muscle collapse in the retropalatal area;

It's important to ensure the eligibility of participants for both study arms. For the experimental arm, we could include individuals who have been diagnosed by an Ear, Nose, and Throat specialist as having a risk of obstructive sleep apnea based on specific criteria and showing pharyngeal muscle collapse in the velopharyngeal area/retropalatal. For the control arm, we could include individuals who meet the same criteria but would not receive any specific intervention. Sure! Here are the full study arms we have designed:

1. Experimental: Myofunctional Therapy Exercise
   - Participant Group/Arm: Seventeen patients who have been diagnosed by an Ear, Nose, and Throat specialist as having a risk of obstructive sleep apnea and showing pharyngeal muscle collapse in the velopharyngeal area/retropalatal.
   - Intervention/Treatment: These participants will perform myofunctional therapy exercises two times per day for 20 minutes every day for six weeks. The exercises will target muscles in the soft palate, tongue, face, and pharynx. Compliance will be monitored through exercise logs, video submissions, and weekly evaluations by the doctor. The impact of the therapy will be evaluated through flexible nasolaryngoscopy, the Epworth Sleepiness Scale questionnaire, and the Berlin questionnaire to measure snoring intensity and frequency before and after the six-week training period.

2. Control: No Specific Intervention
   - Participant Group/Arm: Seventeen patients who have been diagnosed by an Ear, Nose, and Throat specialist as having a risk of obstructive sleep apnea and showing pharyngeal muscle collapse in the velopharyngeal area/retropalatal.
   - Intervention/Treatment: These participants will not receive any specific intervention. They will undergo the same assessments as the experimental group before and after the six-week period to serve as a comparison.

Abstract:
Background ‐--- Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) has a dismal prognosis, and current treatment strategies are still largely incapable of slowing disease progression. PDAC harbors frequent alterations in the oncoprotein KRAS. The activation of K‐Ras by mutation or altered glycosylation has been demonstrated to promote cancer progression. Targeting KRAS‐related signaling through downstream effectors, such as RAF, may halt disease progression. Purpose ‐--- RAF kinase inhibitors have been studied in clinical trials for PDAC but have not improved outcome. MEOS is an investigational agent that inhibits the activation of RAF by down‐regulating Ras palmitoylation. Phase 2 studies examining MEOS in combination with chemotherapy have been reported. The purpose of this study is to examine the efficacy and safety of MEOS in monotherapy in PDAC. Patients and Methods ‐--- Patient accrual has been completed for this ongoing phase 2 clinical trial. Enrollment criteria include a confirmed diagnosis of Stage III or IV PDAC by histology or cytology, measurable or evaluable disease, age ≥ 18, ECOG performance status ≤ 2, and no prior chemotherapy‐containing systemic therapy. MEOS is administered as a one‐hour intravenous infusion on days 1 and 8, repeated every 28 days. The primary endpoint is overall response rate (ORR) by RECIST as evaluated by an independent review committee. Secondary endpoints include progression‐free survival (PFS) and safety. Results ‐--- As of July 15, 2016, 65 patients have been treated and evaluated for response. The median age was 66, median ECOG performance status was 1, and 33% were female. KRAS mutation status was available for 46% of patients, and wild‐type disease was found in 31%. Treatment‐related toxicities have been mostly low grade as expected. Brief Summary

This is a clinical trial to evaluate the safety and tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of ROSE12 and its combination with other anti-tumor agents (e.g., Atezolizumab) in patients with advanced/metastatic solid tumors.

Official Title
-----------------
A Phase 1, Multicenter Trial of the Safety, Tolerability, Pharmacokinetics, and Pharmacodynamics of ROSE12 in Combination With Atezolizumab or Chemotherapy in Patients With Advanced/Metastatic Solid Tumors

MRI to observe cardiac function.

Brief Summary
=================
We have carried out an observational study to evaluate the progression of cardiac function in cardiomyopathies with heart MRI using a short acquisition cardiac sequence. This is important because the lack of cardiac tissue is a key determining factor for future heart failure and cardiac transplant. We also investigate the relationship between the change in cardiac function and the patient's state of health (New York Heart Association) and cardiac remodelling.

Detailed Description
=================
Patients who had an elective heart MRI to observe cardiac function were surveyed. In addition, various examinations such as blood examination, urine examination, chest x-rays and electrocardiograms were performed for each patient. The change in cardiac function was evaluated by comparing the data (short axis view) measured in the patients with that of healthy people with age- and gender-adjusted normal values. The study is approved by the ethics committee of our institute (IRB approval number: E1903) and the Clinical Studies Center of our facilities.

Study Overview
=================

Brief Summary
-----------------
A randomized, multicenter, double-blind study comparing the efficacy of Tibolone 2.5 mg and 1000 µg. CYP19 inhibitor (Tamoxifen 20 mg and Letrozole 2.5 mg) in female breast cancer patients undergoing tamoxifen therapy. The end point of this study will be the incidence of CYP19 inhibitor-resistant cells in tumor-related tissue.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a randomized, multicenter, double-blind study comparing the efficacy of Tibolone 2.5 mg and 1000 µg of tibolone in the inhibition of CYP19 in breast cancer patients under Tamoxifen treatment. The primary aim of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of tibolone in the inhibition of CYP19 in human ER-positive breast cancer patients and evaluate the time course of the CYP19 inhibitory effect. This trial consists of two different arms. Arm A will receive tibolone 2.5 mg and arm B will receive tibolone 1000 µg. All patients will also receive tibolone for two weeks prior to surgery, as well as during an additional four weeks after surgery to monitor the CYP19 status of their tumors. The primary endpoint will be evaluated at least 10 days after stopping tibolone treatment, which will then be compared to the time-course of CYP19 inhibition. The primary endpoint is the percentage of CYP19-negative tumors in patients receiving tibolone. Secondary endpoints are: The difference in time needed for a decrease in the number of CYP19-positive tumors and the time needed for the number of CYP19-negative tumors to reach 80%. Changes in hormone receptor status and AUC/AUCB values before and after tibolone treatment. Safety and tolerability of tibolone, with special emphasis on tamoxifen. Pharmacokinetics of tibolone.
